Issues.Title: Add headers to lazy loading requests
Issues.Body:
# üöÄ feature request

### Relevant Package
This feature request is for @angular/router

### Description
My application has some lazy loaded routes.
Depending on the user, I need to send them a slightly different module, with different features available. I don't want a web developer to simply issue a get request for the module and uncover the features that might be available to different users, so a route guard would not work. I'd like to attach a header for the requests for these lazy loaded modules, so my server can check the user's capabilities and respond with the correct module to lazy load.

### Describe the solution you'd like
Provide a way to append headers to lazy loaded module requests

### Describe alternatives you've considered
Server side rendering, but the goals of this process are quite different, and would involve signifcant rework of an app for what could otherwise be a small feature

Issues.Title: fix(ivy): incorrectly remapping certain properties that refer to inputs
Issues.Body:
During build time we remap particular property bindings, because their names don't match their attribute equivalents (e.g. the property for the `for` attribute is called `htmlFor`). This breaks down if the particular element has an input that has the same name, because the property gets mapped to something invalid.

The following changes address the issue by mapping the name during runtime, because that's when directives are resolved and we know all of the inputs that are associated with a particular element.

Issues.Title: fix(ivy): query projected child elements by directive
Issues.Body:
Context discvery needs to find a TNode based LView and a native element.
Before this change the algorithm was to traverse TNode tree following
child / next links between nodes. The problem with this approach is that
content projection can change TNodes relationship in a way that it is
impossible to reach all the nodes created in a given LView.

There are several ways we could go about fixing this problem. This WIP
PR takes the simplest possible approach and just iterates over all the
native nodes in a given view (we don't care about nodes relationship here
but simply looking up a node).

But the issue being fixed here also unearths an important problem -
content projection _is_ modifying TView structure (TNode relationship)
in a way that makes nodes traversal challenging. In other words each
node traversal algorithm will have to take content projection into account.
There are different things we could do to remedy this problem:

- change data structures so the projection doesn't modify original
  relationship between nodes;

- write a utility function / iterator that can traverse TView nodes
  taking projection into account;

- stick with the approach from this PR.

Opening a WIP PR so we can discuss.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(ivy): query projected child elements by directive" (#28759)

Issues.Title: Add something like ngModelChange to ngForm
Issues.Body:
I want to autosave my `student` object each time a field is edited.

I have a form like
```
 <form #form="ngForm"> 
        <input name="name"
               #name="ngModel"
               [(ngModel)]="student.name">
        <-- many other inputs -->
```
and I tried to make something like 

```
    ngForm.valueChanges.subscribe(x => {
      if (ngForm.form.dirty && ngForm.form.valid) {
        this.service.updateStudent(this.student).subscribe();
      }
    });
```
to detect the changes on each input and save it to the server each time an input is edited. The problem is the model gets updated after `valueChanges` completes. So, following [this](https://github.com/angular/angular/issues/3406) issue, I added `(ngModelChange)="myF()"` to my form`<form #form="ngForm" (ngModelChange)="myF()">`  but nothing happened because there is no output `ngModelChange` on `ngForm`. 

I don't want to attach the `ngModelChange` event on each input field, because is repetitive and ugly. I know that I can use debouce (i.e. `ngForm.valueChanges.pipe(debounceTime(300))`); in this simple case when I update the student is more than enough, but maybe I want to do something else with my `student` model and using deboude will (for example) cause a bad user experience.

Note that the `x` parameter from `subscribe` is not the model object (i.e. the `student` object).

How about adding an Ouput  (or an observable to `ngForm`)  called `ngFormModelChange` (or whatever) which will be called **after** the model is changed, not before (like `valueChanges` does)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Add something like ngModelChange to ngForm" (#28758)

Issues.Title: DebugNode.componentInstance
Issues.Body:
This PR documents in test behaviour of both view engine and ivy when it comes to `DebugNode. componentInstance ` logic. 

The ve semantics seems to be, for a given `DebugNode`:

* if a node is a host for a component, return this component instance
* if a node has no associated component move to a parent node and go back to the previous step;
* if there are no more parent nodes to check return a component that created a given `DebugNode`.


To be honest I find the view engine behaviour rather confusing and I've got no idea why we would go into the business of traversing up the nodes tree - after all we are asking for something associated with a given node and not some random node upwards.

For me the current ivy implementation makes much more sense (just return a component instance if a given node is a host node for a component). Given this I would vote to stick with the current ivy behaviour and mark this as a breaking change.


I'm splitting this PR into 2 parts (test documenting ve behaviour and second commit with adjustments for ivy) so we can easily go back-and-forth on ivy semantics.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "DebugNode.componentInstance" (#28756)

Issues.Title: fix(@angular-devkit/build-angular): disable by default stylesheet root relative URL rebasing
Issues.Body:
BREAKING CHANGE:
Root relative URLs are a standardized method to reference a resource path from the root of a host.  The previous behavior of the Angular CLI prevented this from occuring and resulted in an inability to reference stylesheet assets in this manner.  The initial reason for this behavior is no longer present in the internal implementation of the Angular CLI.  Therefore, this now unnecessary and non-standard behavior is being phased out.  If an application currently relies on this behavior, a compatibility option `rebaseRootRelativeCssUrls` has been provided for the 8.x release cycle to facilitate transition away from this non-standard and limiting behavior.  The recommended method to transition is to use relative paths within the source stylesheet.  This allows the build system to process and generate a full URL for the asset.

``@angular/pwa`` needs to update the ``index.html`` to reference the web app manifest and it also needs to put the manifest into the assets array in the ``angular.json`` file.

To find the ``index.html`` files in question, it looks ups the targets that use specific builders (``@angular-devkit/build-angular:browser``, ``@angular-devkit/build-angular:karma``). To the same targets, it adds the manifest file as an asset.

Hence, ``@angular/pwa`` does not work, if one uses custom builders instead of the two mentioned ones.

To solve this, we could just directly update the targets with specific names, like ``build`` or ``test``.

- ng new myproject
- replace your builders in angular.json with custom ones (just edit the ``builder`` nodes; I don't think that the mentioned builders need to exist for this reproduction)
- ng add @angular/pwa
- Find out that the ``index.html`` has NOT been updated and that the manifest is not included into the ``assets`` array in your ``angular.json``

Issues.Title: Mat-Bottom-Sheet renders incorrectly in IE
Issues.Body:
In internet explorer, Mat-bottom-sheet-container will be visible for one frame, before moving to the bottom of the screen. This causes a visible "flash". This is caused by IE incorrectly painting elements before calculating their styles.

This can be fixed by adding "opacity: 0" to the mat-bottom-sheet css class, and then changing opacity to 1 in javascript one animation frame after invoking "open". 

This has no ill effects on standards compliant browsers, because they will correctly calculate the style of the sheet before painting to the screen, where it will always be opaque. For IE, the bottom sheet will be visible for one less frame, but will otherwise render the same as in other browsers.

Issues.Title: A question on z-index measurements
Issues.Body:
#### What is the expected behavior?
Z-index settings of components should match the DP concept from the [Material Design Elevations](https://material.io/design/environment/elevation.html#default-elevations)

#### What is the current behavior?
Without checking all the available elements, a Dialog is supposed to have a DP of 24. The current angular design has it at 1000. 

#### What are the steps to reproduce?
Open the dialog in the documentation and check the z-index value of the component. 


#### Which versions of Angular, Material, OS, TypeScript, browsers are affected?
7.3.1, likely others


#### Is there anything else we should know?
Nope. I am ok if you choose to tell me to go fly a kite, but we are building web components that match the specifications to the best of our abilities. For developers that use our components along with angular material, this can cause some consternation since our autocomplete component has a body-attached popup that sits at a z-index of 24. We can set it higher, but this creates a brittleness should you choose to change the elevations on yours. 

I am curious what might be a our best options for both maintaining the spec (at least in spirit) and remain easily inter-operable with libraries that are also intended to be compatible to the specification? 

Any help is appreciated. Thanks!
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "A question on z-index measurements" (#15204)

Issues.Title: bug(typography): custom letter-spacing is not taking into account
Issues.Body:
#### What is the expected behavior?
Typography levels should apply custom letter-spacing defined in mat-typography-level() function when a custom typography is created

#### What is the current behavior?
letter-spacing is hardcoded in each level. Example : 
`.mat-display-4, #{$selector} .mat-display-4 {
    @include mat-typography-level-to-styles($config, display-4);
    margin: 0 0 56px;
    letter-spacing: -0.05em;
  }
`

#### What are the steps to reproduce?
Create a custom typo with letter-spacing defined at any level :
`  
$display-4: mat-typography-level(86px, 86px, 400, $my-super-font, 2.2px),
`
The letter spacing is still -0.05em

#### Which versions of Angular, Material, OS, TypeScript, browsers are affected?
I'm on : 
Angular 7.2.4 
Angular Material 7.3.1

MacOS 10.13.6
